title: northern-irelands-covid-cert-scheme-set-become-legally-enforceable
story: Northern Irelandrsquos Covid certication scheme is set to become legally enforceable on Monday.The scheme requiring people to prove Covid status to gain entry to a range of hospitality venues and larges attendance events was introduced late last month with a two-week grace period to allow businesses adjust to the new requirements.Patrons wishing to access nightclubs, pubs, restaurants and other licensed premises will need to provide proof of vaccination or a negative lateral flow test result or evidence of a previous Covid- infection.The same rules will apply for entry to large indoor and outdoor events, such as concerts and sporting events.The regulations that give legal weight to the new system will be subject to a vote in the Stormont Assembly on Monday afternoon.vw,vw,px, px"Health Minister Robin Swann wrote to MLAs at the weekend urging them to back the regulations in the Assembly vote It is unlikely that the law changes will be voted down.While the DUP opposed the scheme at the Stormont Executive last month, branding it a distraction that would have marginal effect in suppressing the transmission of Covid-, the coalitionrsquos other four parties supported its introduction.If the parties vote the same way in the Assembly, the regulations should pass with ease in a straight majority vote.Under the regulations, businesses who repeatedly fail to administer the scheme could face fines of up to pound,.Ahead of the Assembly debate, Health Minister Robin Swann appealed to MLAs to back the scheme. He said the emergence of the Omicron iant had strengthened the case for introducing the system.In a letter sent to all Assembly Members, seen by the PA news agency, Mr Swann called for a ldquorespectful debate on the measures and said opponents should set out their preferred alternatives.ldquoWhile I am confident this measure will be supported by a majority of MLAs, I wanted to underline some key points, not least for those who have still to make up their minds, he wrote..removeldquoFirstly, it needs to be recognised that Covid certication is a public health measure. By introducing it, the Executive and the Assembly will be following public health advice.ldquoThe Chief Medical Officerand Chief Scientic Adviserhave both recommended the initiative to help reduce the risk of infection in higher risk settings.Mr Swann added that he believed the rationale for certication was ldquowell captured in the Executiversquos Autumn Winter Covid- contingency plan issued by DUP First Minister Paul Givan and Sinn Fein deputy First Minister Michelle OrsquoNeill in October.ldquoIn spite of the dferences of opinion in the Assembly on this measure, I would appeal for a respectful debate on Monday, he said.ldquoThe situation we are now facing with Covid demands that of us all.ldquoCertication is certainly not a panacea and will need to be complemented by widespread adherence to public health advice. It does, however, offer another layer of protection to our citizens.ldquoI would encourage opponents of the scheme to spell out their preferred alternatives.vw,vw,px, px"DUP First Minister Paul Givan is opposed to the Covid certication scheme The letter continued: ldquoSimply shouting lsquonorsquo whilst failing to come forward with any genuine alternatives is not a credible position and itrsquos not a luxury that I as Minister of Health, or any of us as MLAs, can afford in the midst of public health emergency.ldquoThere have been no easy answers or simple policy choices in this pandemic. That has been the case for governments across the world.ldquoIt does not serve the public interest to be ducking decisions or constantly criticising from the sidelines.ldquoI commend certication to you as a proportionate policy, that has been introduced in other jurisdictions, and can help keep people safer, business open and support our health service this winter.ldquoThe emerging Omicron threat demonstrates the continued risk from the virus and further strengthens the case for certication..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Northern Ireland us Covid cert scheme set to become legally enforceable

title: covid-scotland-booster-jabs-appear-vaccine-passports-december-9
story: Scotlands deputy first minister confirmed this morning that the Covid booster jab will appear on Scottish vaccine passports for internationaltravel from December .Speaking on Good Morning Scotland, John Swinney said that proof of the booster jab would appear on vaccine passports for international travel from Thursday December .He added that this would be extended to the domestic vaccine certicationscheme, however this would take slightly longer to implement.When asked whether booster jabs would be included in the vaccine passport scheme, the deputy first minister said: "For international travelit will from  December."And we will expand that for domestic certication but that will take us a little more time to do that. But the critical requirement is for international travel and those changes will be applied from  December."How to get proof of booster jab on vaccine passport According to the Scottish government, the NHSScotlandCovid Status app will update on Thursday December  to show proof of the booster jab.Depending on the settings on your phone, this will either update automatically or will require you to do it manually.If you need to update your app manually, you can do so by going to the app store and clicking on the small person icon in the top right corner.This will take you to your account details, where it will show you a list of the apps you have downloaded on your phone.Next to the app, there should be an option to update.The Scottish government has said that it will take dfering times for the update to roll out everywhere, but that it is currently underway as of lunch time on Thursday.Why is it important that boosters show on vaccine passports To travel to some countries, you must have been fully vaccinated against Covidwithin a certain time limitprior to your visit, which ranges from -days to a year.With Covid jabs rolled out from late last year, it means that some people will already be barred from travelthey cannot provide proof of a booster jab..removeProof of a booster jab will therefore help people to meet the vaccination requirements of certain countries.Who can get a booster jab in Scotland All adults in Scotland will be offered a booster vaccine as advised by the JCVI after results showed a third vaccine signicantly improved protection against serious infection.The booster jabs aim to curb a potentialwave of infections caused by the Omicron iant.So far, everyone aged  and over and people who are clinically vulnerable have been invited to book their booster jabs in Scotland.But soon, everyone over the age of  will beable to book a booster jab.These third doses will be offered no less than three months after the second dose of the vaccine was administered.This time frame between second vaccine and booster jab has been cut from six months to three, as advised by the JCVI.

title: covid-scotland-get-proof-booster-jab-vaccine-passport-app
story: Proof of booster jabs on the Scottish NHS Covid Status app will become available fromThursday December , according to the Scottish government.To travelto some countries, you must have been fully vaccinated against Covidwithin a certain time limitprior to your visit, which ranges from -days to a year.With Covid jabs rolled out from late last year, it means that some people will already be barred from travelthey cannot provide proof of a booster jab.Proof of a third vaccinewill therefore help people to meet the vaccination requirements of certain countries.While proof of booster jabs was introduced in England in November, the update of the Scottish NHS vaccine passport app is taking place today.Heres how to get proof of the booster jab for internationaltravel.How to get proof of the booster jab for international travel According to the Scottish government, the NHS ScotlandCovid Status app will update today to show proof of the booster jab.Depending on the settings on your phone, this will either update automatically or will require you to do it manually.If you need to update your app manually, you can do so by going to the app store and clicking on the small person icon in the top right corner.This will take you to your account details, where it will show you a list of the apps you have downloaded on your phone.Next to the app, there should be an option to update.The Scottish government has said that it will take dfering times for the update to roll out everywhere, but that it is currently underway as of lunch time on Thursday.How to download theNHS Scotland Covid Status AppYou can download your vaccine passporton your smartphonevia theNHS Scotland Covid Status App.Simply head to the app store on your device and search NHS Scotland Covid Status App, which is free to download.You must firstly read andagree to the privacy policy which explains how the app works..removeThen you can either sign-inyou have previously made an account or sign upyou are yet to create one.If you are signing up, it will ask you to very your identity by uploading a photo of your passport or driving license and scanning your face with your camera.Once you have veried your identity, you can sign up by entering your email address and sending a verication code to this address.It will then ask you to enter the verication code before creating a password and confirming your account.You will be asked for your CHI number, however it is not a problemyou dont know it - you can skip this step by clicking "No" whenaskedyou know your number.The app will then display your name and date of birth as shown on your ID, and ask for the gender towhich you identy.You must then create a memorable  number pin.This is the final step in creating your account.The app should then show your vaccine status, including details of initial twojabs and the booster vaccine, barcodes for each and theof time since each of these vaccinations.Each time you sign into the app you will be asked to enter the memorable code.

title: covid-scotland-current-restrictions
story: Boris Johnson announced further Covid restrictions in England on Wednesday, but what are the rules in Scotland The Scottish government is responsible for its own response to the pandemic, and therefore implements its own restrictions and measures surrounding Covid.While the prime minister yesterday implemented new measures in England, many of these were already in place in Scotland.Here is everything you need to know about the current Covid restrictions in Scotland...What are the current Covid measures in Scotland These are the current Covid regulations in place in Scotland:masks and face coverings on publictransport, in shops and when moving around in hospitality settingsCovid vaccine passport scheme - proof of vaccination or a negative lateral flow test required in nightclubs,indoor live events with + people unseated, outdoor live events with + peopleunseated and any event with ,+ peoplework from home has been urged wherever possible, with the government saying anyone who worked from home at the beginning of the pandemic should do so againWhat are the isolation rules in Scotland There are dferent rules depending on whether it is the newOmicron iant or the Delta iant.Anyone who tests positive forOmicron iant in Scotland must self isolate for  days.All close contacts of suspected Omicron infections must self isolate for -days, whether they are fully vaccinated or not.People will be told when they receive their PCR resultsthey have the Omicron iant.Anyone who tests positive for any iant of Covid- must self-isolate for -days.However,this is not the Omicron iant there are dferent rules for close contacts who are fully vaccinated.If you are fully vaccinated and a close contact of someone who tests positive for non-Omicron Covid, you must isolate until you get a PCR test.Ifyourresult then comes back negative and youremain asymptomatic, you will no longer have to isolate..removeHoweveryou are not vaccinated or only partially vaccinated and are identied as a close contact of someone with Covid,you must isolate for -days regardless of the result of your PCR test.What are thetravelrules for Scotland The travelrules are the same across the UK.Everyone travelling from overseas must take a pre-departure and post-arrival test regardless of vaccination status.You must take a test within -hours before your flightto the UK, and test within -hours of your arrival in the UK, isolating until you receive these results.If you are fully vaccinated and receive a negative result, you can leave isolation.If you are not fully vaccinated you must isolate for -days and take a further day- test.If you are travelling from a country on the red list, you must isolate in a quarantine hotel.Will more restrictions be introduced in Scotland Tweeting on Wednesday night, first minister Nicola Sturgeon said: "Re UK gov announcement of Covid Plan B today, all these protections are already in place in and have helped us get Delta cases down."Tough question we all face in period ahead is whether these protections will be strong enough against a rapidly spreading Omicron ianthellip"Even Omicron doesnrsquot cause more severe disease, the numbers of people who might be infected by its faster spread will create big challenges for NHS and economy- so we need to consider carefullywhat proportionate response needed."In meantime, all of us complying strictly with current protections will help. And evenyou feel angry with a politician just now, please remember just how important compliance is for the healthsafety of you, your loved ones and the country"

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as ldquoa real dream come true.She said: ldquoWe are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk ndash The Cheese Lady ndash has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: ldquoWe needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.ldquoWe want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.ldquoAlso, Irsquom hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: ldquoWhoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  Thatrsquos fantastic.ldquoAnd it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: ldquoI think we are in a good place.ldquoWhen we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than pound,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: ldquoWe are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.ldquoMary has raised a fantastic pound, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised pound, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Romanrsquos Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: ldquoThis year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.ldquoIrsquom walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: rising-star-joins-east-festival-2022-line-up
story: He will join headliners The Kooks and Ministry of Sound Classical, plus Shed Seven, Circa Waves, Sister Sledge and The Futureheads.The two-day, family-friendly festival will feature a erse blend of live music, street food, art, culture and wellbeing events on August  and  next year.Callum played a special set ahead of Scotlandrsquos first Autumn Nations Series rugby match against Tonga at Murrayfield in October has had a sold-out Scottish tour and will be supporting fellow Scottish musician Amy Macdonald on her UK tour, including a show at the OVO Hydro in Glasgow this month.Callumrsquos debut album, People Like Us, reached No.  in The Official Scottish Album Chart and No.  in The Official UK Album Sales Charts last year.Shane Grieve, Out East Festival director, said: ldquoWersquore back, bigger and better for . The summer will be all about celebrating the good things in le and wersquore delighted that Out East will be at the centre of that.Stephen Begg, operations manager at Dalkeith Country Park, added: ldquoWe are ecstatic to be hosting Out East Festival  at Dalkeith Country Park. We canrsquot wait. The parkrsquos expanse of beautul greenery is the perfect backdrop for this vibrant music, art and culture-focussed, family-friendly event.In addition to the musical line-up, Out East will offer a well-being area, lsquoThe Breakoutrsquo, nestled amongst the trees with wildle.At lsquoThe Outpostrsquo, an open-air cabaret stage, an eclectic mix of art and culture, including comedy and dance theatre, will take place. Everything from storytelling, science and circus activities is available at lsquoSchoolrsquos Outrsquo, while lsquoThe Pig Outrsquo will be curated by Canteen, offering ious culinary delights. A fairground can also be enjoyed at lsquoFar Outrsquo.For more information, go to outeastfest

title: josh-taylor-putting-aside-friendship-lee-catterall-ahead-title-defence
story: The Prestonpans man has no issues with the mandatory challenger from Chorley, who was in Las Vegas in May backing Taylor when he unied all four light-welterweight belts with a convincing decision win over the previously undefeated Jose Ramirez, which also extended his unbeaten record to -.Speaking at The Royal Scots Club in Edinburgh, where both boxers were publicising their fight at The SSE Hydro Arena, -year-old Taylor revealed a changed attitude towards Catterall, also unbeaten with a - record and a former British and WBO Intercontinental champion.The WBC, WBA, IBF and WBO champion said: ldquoI like Jack. I have a lot of time for him. There is no bad blood there, there never has been.ldquoBut the mindset towards him now changes and that is easy for me.ldquoI can change the mindset with a click of my fingers. I am a fighting man and it is easy to change that mindset.ldquoI am getting sick of looking at his face already. I just want to get in the ring and beat him up and keep my beltsldquoAt the end of the day, he is coming for what I worked so hard to achieve. I came up the hard way, I had to beat champion after champion, undefeated fighter after undefeated fighter, so he is getting the chance of all this glory in one fight.ldquoIt is my job to make sure he gets nowhere near it. I donrsquot think he will bring anything I havenrsquot seen before and he hasnrsquot fought anywhere near the level that I have. This will be a telling factor on fight night.Fans can sign up for pre-sale tickets at boxxer

title: musselburgh-racecourse-fans-staff-don-christmas-jumpers-charity
story: The Seven National Hunt races over jumps got racing fans in the festive spirit and trackside they were encouraged to wear festive jumpers to raise money for the Injured Jockeys Fund.Racecourse staff played their part by sporting their own festive knitwear at the Scottish Racing Academy Christmas Jumper Race Day.SRA members took a collection for the Injured Jockeys Fund, founded in  to support jockeys who are injured, unable to ride or in need of assistance.The SRArsquos equicizer ndash a racing simulator ndash was onsite and racegoers were able to test their potential to be a jockey, with scores kept throughout the day.Aisling Johnston, Musselburgh Racecourse marketing manager, said: ldquoEveryone loves to pull on a Christmas jumper and we were delighted that racegoers got right into the Christmas spirit and helped us raise funds for the very deserving Injured Jockeyrsquos Fund.Hannah Farrell, of The Scottish Racing Academy, said: ldquoWe were very happy to support Musselburgh Racecoursersquos Christmas Jumper festivities, and it was an added bonus that the Injured Jockeyrsquos charity benefited from this generous initiative.Musselburgh Racecourse is back in action on December .For more information and to book tickets, visit www.musselburgh-racecourse

title: residents-launch-campaign-tranent-pubs-closure-sold-housing
story: Hawthorn Leisure, which owns The Tower Inn, notied husband-and-we duo John and Tracy Reynolds, who have run the pub for the last nine years, that the building had been sold.The pub, established in , has served the local community for nearly  years but staff at the well-loved watering hole will pour the pubrsquos final pint on January  ndash leaving just three public houses in the town: Whispers, The Brig Inn and The Tranent Arms.John, , expressed his sadness at losing the pub and said: ldquoThere will certainly have been a few stories told over the last century inside this place.ldquoIt has also been the site where a lot of friendships have been made and jobs created over the years.ldquoWe have all shared lots of laughter, tears of joy and sadness, and each of us will have our own little memories but, sadly, Tranent is losing another community hub.ldquoTracy and I would like to thank everyone over the last nine years for their custom and support, and not to mention the numerous amount of friends we have made during our time here.ldquoWe also remember the characters and friends who are no longer with us, some of whom were the most loyal customers we have ever come across.ldquoCovid has not been kind to a lot of businesses, particularly those in the hospitality sector, but as the saying goes, lsquouse it or lose itrsquo, which will apply to the remainder of pubs and clubs that are left in Tranent.The pub was put up for sale earlier in the year, with Mr and Mrs Reynolds only finding out about its sale status a week before it re-opened following the relaxation of Covid- restrictions on May .Now, Tower Inn punters are banding together to save the establishment from closure.A Facebook page ndash titled Save the Tower Inn ndash has gathered more than  followers upon its creation.Victor Nelson, Save the Tower Inn spokesperson, said: ldquoIt is a pub that has maintained its traditions over the years, providing a warm and friendly atmosphere as well as much-needed support and friendships to those in the community that have needed it most.ldquoIn recent years, the Tower has set up a menrsquos social group which raised money to donate to local community projects.ldquoThis provided assistance towards buying memorial benches for use within the community and also gave the Hub at Sandersonrsquos Wynd Primary the money to buy two communication devices to give non-verbal pupils a voice.ldquoEarlier this year, the brewery that owned the pub put the Tower Inn up for sale and invited offers to all parties with the view to selling the property to the highest bidder.ldquoA number of the interested parties submitted offers that would have continued to run the property as a pub but sadly failed in the highest bid process, meaning the property has now been sold for residential purposes that will see the pub close its doors for the final time mid January  ndash a sad loss that will see people lose their jobs, East Lothian lose another traditional establishment and the community lose another local hub.Kenny McLeod, ward councillor, said: ldquoI am disappointed to see another pub shut in Tranent after well over  years since it opened ndash another gathering place for people of Tranent to meet and catch up.ldquoWe have lost so many establishments such as the Legion, Labour Club and The Plough.ldquoWe now only have Whispers, The Brig Inn and The Tranent Arms left when it comes to pubs, but we still have the Store Club and the rugby club, along with the bowling clubs available.A spokesperson for Hawthorn said: ldquoWe are strong believers in the importance of community pubs.ldquoUnfortunately, despite our best efforts, we have been unable to find a new partner to take over The Tower Inn when our current tenantrsquos lease ends in January, so we have taken the decision to sell the pub.

title: new-3-4m-early-years-facility-construction-pushed-back-2023
story: Work on the two-storey nursery building is now anticipated to start early next year, with an -month timeframe for the build in place.The facility will be built west of Law Primary School and will replace the townrsquos current nursery, behind the community centre on Law Road.New drawings for the planned structure were filed late last month.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoNew documents were submitted to planning in response to parent council and planning department comments, as part of the planning process.ldquoThe application has not been decided upon yet.The original construction date of summer this year was delayed due to Covid- and ldquoimpacts on the construction industry, the spokesperson added.They said: ldquoThe new early years centre will provide ample space for learning and play to accommodate a growing population.ldquoBeing adjacent to the primary school will offer better opportunities for activities between children in the two facilities and support the transition to Primary .ldquoAlongside the carefully designed internal spaces, the outside area will include a kitchen garden and large playground.ldquoWe will continue to update the community as the project progresses.A spokesperson for Law Primary Parent Council said: ldquoThe parent council are frustrated by the delay.ldquoAs a parent group, we can see the benefits the new building will bring to the children of North Berwick.ldquoWe know the nursery staff do a tremendous job, regardless of resources however, there is no doubt that the new building will be a fantastic asset to the community.ldquoWe have been working with the council during the consultation process to ensure there are well-thought-out paths to allow safe and easy pedestrian access from every part of town and are excited about seeing the final designs.ldquoOur hope is for a nurturing, playful space for our children in the present, but also a climate-friendly building for the future that will lead the way as school estates across East Lothian develop and expand.The new nursery, which will have capacity for  children over two sessions, has an open-plan design, with a mezzanine area and separate quiet room.The contract value of the nursery is pound.m, with a further pound, due to be spent on internal fittings.North of the site, a three-classroom extension for secondary school pupils is being built on the south-west side of North Berwick High School. This pound. million project, due to be complete next autumn, will house new home economics, modern languages and social studies classrooms for the high school.

title: trees-remembrance-lit-memory-lost-loved-ones
story: St Columbarsquos Hospice Care unveiled a Tree of Remembrance in Edinburgh on Monday, with a second tree, in St Maryrsquos Pleasance Courtyard, being lit at .pm.A special service is open to all, not just those with a connection to the hospice, which provides hospice care for people living in the area free of charge.The lights on the Trees of Remembrance symbolise dedications made by supporters across Edinburgh and the Lothians in memory of people who have died.Classical musician Ciara Harvie, of Longniddry, will also perform at the service in Haddington.Jackie Stone, St Columbarsquos Hospice Care chief executive, highlighted the importance of the annual appeal.She said: ldquoLight up a Le is a hugely important appeal for us, as it brings the St Columbarsquos Hospice Care community together at what can be a time of mixed emotions for many who are remembering a loved one.ldquoThe donations we received last year, in excess of pound,, helped us to reach patients and families across Edinburgh and East Lothian.ldquoThe money raised this year will enable us to bring world-leading palliative care to even more of the people who need it in our communities.Anyone is welcome to attend a service ndashemail fund@stcolumbashospice.org.uk to pass on details.The trees will remain lit throughout the festive period until January .Dedications can be made online throughout December at stcolumbashospice.org.uk light-up-a-le- or by calling   .

title: dunbar-housing-plans-holes-like-swiss-cheese
story: Concerns were raised that funds requested from developers to cover some of the infrastructure costs connected to the plans for  homes were based on costs that had not been updated for over a decade.And the local community council said work which had already been promised before previous housing was built had not been carried out ndash leaving the roads and pedestrian networks around the area at breaking point.Dunbar community councillor Jacquie Bell told the planning committee at its online meeting on Tuesday: ldquoThis proposal has infrastructure holes like Swiss cheese, questions that need resolving and time constraints when we need time to review.The committee was asked to approve Taylor Wimpey plans for  houses and  flats at Hallhill, Dunbar, in the final phase of a wider development in the area.Among contributions agreed between the developers and planners was pound, towards a bridge or crossing for the East Coast Main Rail Line which will be needed as part of the infrastructure of the estate.: Bid to sell alcohol from Hallhill Sports CentreEast Lothian councillor Jeremy Findlay, a committee member, raised concerns that the contribution was based on a cost for the crossing which had not been updated since .But while planners admitted that it was likely the cost for the work now would be far higher and the council was likelyto face some shortfall, they insisted the contribution had been calculated using an index to cover inflation.Councillor Lachlan Bruce asked: ldquoIs it usual to use decade-old figures for determining contributions for infrastructure for a development to go ahead He was told it was not normally the case but recalculating the cost of such a complex project could take years.Mrs Bell said that the community council had concerns which had grown in recent years as housing in parts of the estate had been built and families moved in.She said concerns about one access route, Hospital Road, had been dismissed in  by the Scottish GovernmentReporter who said it would not be used.She said: ldquoIt is now collapsing and heavily used.: Fate of rail underpass depends on housing decisionAnd she said ongoing concerns over the junction onto the A from the estate remained unresolved, adding: ldquoThe junction urgently needs an upgrade so it is galling to see developer contributions go to junctions  miles away.Mrs Bell said pedestrians were in conflict with vehicles on the roads around the estate and urged the committee to consider a continuation of a decision on the planning application until more answers could be sought.Councillor Findlay moved a motion for a delay to the decision, citing a need to update the contributions being requested for the East Coast Main Line crossing but was defeated by eight votes to three.The committee then approved the plans by  votes to one with only Councillor Findlay against.A further application for  houses at Windygoul in Tranent was unanimously approved during the virtual meeting of the committee.The application was part of a wider development in Tranent and received no objections.

title: two-county-academics-given-key-roles-university
story: Professor Catriona Bell, who has lived in Dunbar for the past  years, will take up the new post of director of academic development and learning enhancement, while Professor David Stevenson, who has lived in Musselburgh for four years, takes on the permanent role of dean of the School of Arts, Social Sciences and Management .Professor Bell will provide strategic leadership of the enhancement of learning, teaching and assessment across the portfolio of the university, including domestic and international collaborative partnerships and online learning portfolio. She comes to QMU from Advance HE, where she has served as head of membership for Scotland and senior advisor in learning and teaching since February , and with more than  yearsrsquo academic experience at two Russell Group universities, latterly as a reader in veterinary education.Professor Bell has gained the highest level of professional recognition for learning and teaching, becoming a Principal Fellow of the Higher Education Academyin  and a National Teaching Fellowin  ndash the first year that the NTF scheme ran in Scotland. She is also a qualied veterinary surgeon and enjoys wildle watching in her spare time. She took up her new post at QMU on October .Professor Stevenson served as acting dean of ASSAM since the departure of Professor Brigid Daniel in .He took up the permanent role of dean in September after interim management of the school through the Covid- pandemic highlighted his problem-solving, influencing and communication skills, a position he held while continuing his role as director of the Centre for Communication, Cultural and Media Studiesand the Unit of Assessment Leadfor REF .Prior to his current role, Professor Stevenson was head of QMUrsquos media, communication, and performing artsision. During this time, the ision moved up the league tables, in particular within the subject area of drama, dance and cinematics, which, in -, saw MCPA reach its highest ever positions ndash coming sixth in the UK out of  in the Times Good University Guideand third in the UK Good University Guide.Professor Richard Butt, QMUrsquos deputy principal, said: ldquoWe are delighted to announce the appointment of Professor Catriona Bell and Professor David Stevenson to their new roles within the university.ldquoTogether, they will play a key part in shaping the future design and delivery of our academic portfolio, ensuring it continues to offer a high-quality learning experience for students that equips them with the knowledge and skills sought by employers.

title: greenkeepers-superb-actions-save-golfers-life
story: Liam Nicholson, , who has helped maintain the greens at Gullane Golf Club for  years, put his first aid training to good use recently when he attended to a golfer who suffered a heart attack on the course.He used one of the clubrsquos three defibrillators to resuscitate the golfer, and he, his colleagues and the manrsquos playing partners continued treatment until an ambulance arrived.Course manager Stewart Duff said Liamrsquos actions were a ldquogreat effort.He said: ldquoIt was superb because it was the first time Liamrsquos ever done anything like this.ldquoThe chap who is probably our best first aider, the most experienced, was busy in a meeting with me, so Liam got a call and was asked lsquocan you deal with it rsquo, and Liam says yep and he did it, so it was his first time doing it and it was a great effort.The golf club organises regular first aid training for its staff.But Liam himself said he did not ever foresee having to use his le-saving skills.He added: ldquoYou never know day to day what yoursquore going to come up against so yoursquore always ready to be on handsomething ever happens.ldquoObviously you donrsquot really want to have to use the skills yoursquove learned during the first aid training but it happened and I was trained up so I knew what I was doing.The Edinburgh resident, who grew up in Gullane, continued: ldquoI was panicking a bit when I went down the road to the incident but when I got there adrenaline kicked in and everything came naturally to me.ldquoAfterwards I was a bit shaken up but I got a phone call later on at night saying the man was still alive and that my actions had probably saved his le.ldquoI was a wee bit emotional about it. Itrsquos not every day you save someonersquos le.The quick-thinking lesaver was awarded a ldquogenerous gt by the club last week, while the golfer, from East Lothian, is said to be recovering well.

title: residents-invited-transform-homes-streets-window-wanderland
story: Organised by the Fisherrow Waterfront Group and Fisherrow Harbour and Seafront Association, community members are being asked to light up their windows for others to enjoy viewing from tomorrowuntil Sunday, -pm.Displays can be put in one or more windows of flats, houses, businesses, cars, campervans and shops.Images could be created using silhouettes, tissue paper or objects.This yearrsquos loose theme is lsquoWinter Celebrationsrsquo so designs could be based on how winter holidays are celebrated worldwide or what winter means to participants and their families.The organisers are keen that recycled materials such as cereal boxes, tissue paper, cellophane, sugar paper and old Christmas cards are usedpossible.The first Window Wanderland took place amidst the Covid- crisis in the lead-up to Christmas last year.Residents and businesses in the area decorated their windows for the festive season after Christmas family events were cancelled due to coronavirus restrictions.It was a big success, with more than  displays lit up for people to view on three evenings in December, on the loose theme of lsquoWinter Wonderland by the Searsquo.Those who have questions or would like to help with this yearrsquos event should email fisherrowwaterfront@gmailTo take part in the Window Wanderland, go to windowwanderland event fisherrow-musselburgh-

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-1996-1971-1921
story: lsquoMILLIONAIRErsquoS major development plan gets green lightrsquo was front page news in the East Lothian Courier on December , .A multi-million-pound complex of two hotels, a championship golf course, business park and  new houses has been given the green light by planners, despite ten objections.Glasgow millionaire James McNeil was given outline planning permission for the massive project, at Lochend and Hallhill to the East of Dunbar, which is a scaled-down version of a scheme first mooted by him more than six years ago.But the whole development could still be delayed over an access agreement between local farmer Alex Taylor, who sold the farmland to Mr McNeil, allegedly for pound million.Mr Taylor has a planning application in to develop for housing adjoining land he still owns but has not yet reached an access agreement with Mr McNeil.If agreement cannot be reached, his land could not be developed....and  years agolsquoHOUSEWIFE criticises coalboxesrsquo was a headline in The Haddingtonshire Courier on December , .A Haddington woman found nearly all her coal stolen this morning... and this week she blamed the fact that the modern coal box at her Council home is not fitted with locks.There were only three lumps of coal left from the contents of eight bags.Mrs Mary Slavin, of  Lynn Lea Avenue, who moved into her new home in September, said: ldquoI donrsquot understand why there are no locks on the coalboxes.ldquoI just have to leave the coal there and hope for the best.ldquoIt certainly is the silliest situation I have ever come across....and  years agoA PRESTONPANS man was charged for cycling without a light and illegal possession of trout, reported The Haddingtonshire Courier on December , .At a Justice of Peace Court, held in Haddington, on Monday, Michael MrsquoGough, miner,  Cuthill Street, Prestonpans, pleaded guilty to having, on Saturday th November, cycled on the public road between Longniddry and Wallyford without having a lamp on his machine.He said the night was clear, and he did not think a light was necessary.He was fined s d.He was subsequently charged with having on the same date, been found in the illegal possession of twenty-five common trout, it being then the annual close time.An agent stated that the accused on his road home got the trout from a friend.

title: pantomime-fun-way-gullane
story: The cast of Cinderella is raring to go to bring some magic to the town after last yearrsquos panto was cancelled due to the coronavirus pandemic.Performances take place next week on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday from .pm and then next Saturdayfrom noon and pm at Gullane Village Hall.Tickets cost pound for adults and pound for children, with doors opening half an hour before showtime.Tickets will be available to buy from the foyer of Gullane Village Hall between pm and .pm on Sunday.Covid- measures will be in place for the safety of attendees, including extra cleaning and sanitising, additional spacing between seats, temperature checks on arrival and good ventilation.Face coverings must be worn by all attending.

title: county-stations-witness-significant-drop-passengers
story: The coronavirus pandemic had a massive impact on the number of people entering and exiting the countyrsquos seven stations.The numbers were revealed in the Office of Rail and Roadrsquosestimates of station usage statistics -, which include the annual total of passenger entries and exits at the ,-plus stations across Britain.In -, the number of people entering and exiting East Lothianrsquos railway stations was estimated at ,,.In contrast, for the following financial year, the number was thought to be just , ndash an  per cent drop.One of the other notable changes was that North Berwick was no longer the most used station.In -, , used the station but the number fell to ,the following year.Meanwhile, Musselburghrsquos figure dropped from , to ,over the same period.Usage at Dunbar dropped from , people to , , while Wallyfordrsquos fell from , to , .Prestonpansrsquo numbers showed a similar drop ndash , to , , with Longniddry dropping from , to , .Finally, the figures for Drem were , to , .Kenny MacAskill, MP for East Lothian, described the figures as ldquounderstandable but worrying.He said: ldquoAs a regular rail user, I know how vital the service is.ldquoCoronavirus has had an impact but rail is essential for recovery.ldquoProposed cuts in services impact badly and must be resisted. Likewise, the cost remains too high and to encourage passenger , rises must also be resisted.ldquoRail is essential socially, economically and environmentally.Feras Alshaker, director of planning and performance at the Office of Rail and Road, felt there were signs of recovery.He said: ldquoThroughout -, the railways remained an essential service for those people who needed to travel during a year which was impacted by the pandemic.ldquoGlasgow Central has consistently appeared as one of the top  most used stations outside of London and it is clear it remained a key destination for many passengers during the pandemic.ldquoThis year, we have seen many railway stations with very few passenger entries and exits.ldquoHowever, we know that recent figures show leisure journeys are nearly back to pre-pandemic levels, while there has been a slower increase in commuter journeys.ldquoHowever, we know that recent figures show leisure journeys are nearly back to pre-pandemic levels, while there has been a slower increase in commuter journeys.

title: tims-tales-awe-some-christmas
story: Irsquom talking about the first definition, the times when we are amazed or find something so fascinating it makes our brain sparkle.I remember watching a juggler last summer, he was brilliant and we were in awe of his skill. He started juggling with knives and balancing on one leg while standing on a giant ball!He was playing with our senses, he knew exactly how to build suspense and stretch our belief in what we thought was possible. You could hear the silenced hush of awe in the audience watching his performance.Awe is something we all need on a regular basis. In fact,you look at the science, it has a huge impact on our ability to think, investigate, make discoveries and inventions.It stimulates our curiosity and makes us feel more connected, for example to nature, to our community, to history or whatever small wonders we experience every day.John Muir often talked about being awestricken by the natural wonders he experienced. They often overwhelmed his senses and this fed his passion to protect the landscape he revered, resulting in the formation of the national parks in the USA.But his sense of awe enthralled him as a child, as he explored the shore and fields around his home town of Dunbar.Thatrsquos the thing our sense of awe is not confined to grand sights. There are everyday wonders we encounter, and pausing for a moment to feel that sense of being ldquoawe-stricken has such a huge impact on our well-being.Scientists will tell you awe will transform your mind, make you feel humble and more empathetic. Itrsquos an uplting spiritual experience, and I donrsquot mean religious, although awe is an important part of all religions.But you donrsquot have to be religious to be spiritual. And I think being able to feel amazed by the things around us is a spiritual way of being.And at Christmas-time especially, I often feel the ironic contradiction of a celebration that has at its heart a powerful spiritual message, but which has been hijacked to promote the needs of mass consumerism.The pressure to buy at this time can hit hard, especially when paying the bills and putting food on the table is a daily concern for so many. Povertyrsquos cold fingers are creeping into our homes as we try to keep warm. Yet, especiallywe have children, we want our family to feel included and blessed at this time. Who doesnrsquot How hard it is to resist the powerful messages thrown at us that fulfilment and happiness can be bought with the latest updated stuff you buy in shops that the phone you got last year is old now, you need a new one those shoes have the wrong label, you just have to have this because everyone  does. The list could be endless.Unfortunately, you canrsquot buy a sense of awe in the shops. No, wait, actually itrsquos fortunate! If it was something you had to buy then theyrsquod commody it, overprice it and, once yoursquod bought it, tell you it was now obsolete and you needed a new version!Itrsquos going to be an especially hard Christmas for so many of us this year, for so many dferent reasons, including financial ones.I get overwhelmed by it so often, and I often feel guilt that Irsquom not spending enough on gts, even though in my heart I know itrsquos not the cost that ultimately matters but the thought. The consumerist message is so powerful and universal that itrsquos dficult to opt out.But this is where cultivating our sense of awe can be so uplting, at a time when we feel so much pressure. What really makes us happy is relationships, not stuff. A thoughtful gt is part of that of course, but the awe is in the thought put into it.I think feeling a sense of awe is closely linked to being able to truly appreciate what we have and can experience.That includes the gts of kindness and generosity of people, as much as the blazing sunset or frost covered spiderrsquos web we saw a few days ago. Kindness is a gt, like the tolerant and friendly smile a stranger gave me the other day as he waited patiently in his car as I tried to fix my childrsquos seatbelt.My son noticed it too: ldquoThat was a nice man.Thankfully, kindness isnrsquot something you have to buy either itrsquos free and is not just for Christmas.

title: christmas-market-coming-dirleton
story: After a successful first year, Dirleton Market on the Green will hold its final market of the year with a Christmas community event between am and pm.The market will offer a range of Christmas gts by local producers from a iety of stallholders ndash while Santa will make a last-minute visit before the big day.Dirleton School Partnership and Dirleton Playgroup will both have fundraising stalls offering a range of Christmas activities, competitions and prizes.Meanwhile, Dirleton author Keith Cornwell will be on site signing copies of his book Our Man On Mars.The Wee Green Van will offer bagels to keep visitors fed, wile Amalfi will serve hot drinks and ice cream.

title: prestonpans-schoolboy-over-moon-finding-secret-santa-christmas-present
story: Ryan Black was walking home from school on Friday when he discovered the neatly wrapped festive gt near his home in Prestonpans.The seven-year-old was delighted at the find and mum Jen has described the act of kindness as ldquoamazing and praised the Secret Santa organisation responsible.Jen said: ldquoIt is such an amazing thing to do. I am hoping they all get found and bring a smile to everyone who finds the gts.Jen posted a picture of her smiling son and the gt on a local Facebook page and added: ldquoThank you to whoever it is that is leaving gts around the town. My son found one and is over the moon.The childrenrsquos books have been left in towns and cities across the UK by an organisation called Story From Santa and it is thought that hundreds of presents have been placed for children to discover.Organiser Victoria Elwell, from Bristol, said: ldquoI wanted to spread a little Christmas joy this festive season and reading is so important for children.ldquoSo I came up with the idea of Santa gting a story.ldquoI spread the word on Facebook and have had lots of people interested.ldquoToday was the first day to do it and books can be dropped any time between now and Christmas Eve, ideally under the cover of darkness, aka super early.ldquoI personally dropped in Bristol, but I believe they are being spread across the UK.Several parents have also posted on the Pans Folks social media page saying their children have come across the Yuletide gts.One said: ldquoMy granddaughter found one too ndash lovely thing to do.And another added: ldquoUs too. Thank you very much. I had one delighted girl.

title: scottish-greens-reveal-candidates-2022-east-lothian-council-elections
story: At an event in Dunbar with co-leader of the Scottish Greens Lorna Slater MSP, the party confirmed the four candidates who will join Tim Porteus, who was recently confirmed as standing in the Preston Seton Gosford ward.: Storyteller Tim Porteus standing for Greens in Preston Seton Gosford by-electionDavid Mumford will contest the Dunbar  East Linton ward, where the Greens scored their highest vote share in the last East Lothian Council elections in .Innerwick-based David retired as rector of the Scottish Episcopal Church in Brechin in  and, prior to being ordained, worked as a social worker and as head of an international organisation promoting non-violent conflict resolution.A keen swimmer and Brechin City football fan, he said: ldquoI want everyone in East Lothian to be decently housed and I want there to be adequate social care for all who need it.ldquoWe also need to see East Lothian do their part in safeguarding the environment. The more Green Party councillors there are, the more effective we can be.In Musselburgh, the party will be represented by Shona McIntosh.Shona works for Edinburgh Napier University on a project supporting care-experienced learners. She has a young family, is a keen runner and is also active in the campaign to stop the construction of .km of concrete walls around the Musselburgh coast and riverside as part of the towns flood protection scheme.Shona said: ldquoWe must get East Lothian Council to commit to a more ambitious target on reaching net zero and prioritise natural flood defences over concrete walls.ldquoThe council must also listen to young people more on what they want from their education and work harder on tackling inequality in attainment and job prospects.An international environment and development expert will stand for the Greens in North Berwick Coastal.Jacq Cottrell advises governments in developing countries on green economy and sustainability, working for the United Nations and national development agencies.Jacq said: ldquoI have come across so many exciting and innovative ideas for low-carbon transition in my professional le and I would love to use my role as a councillor to bring them to East Lothian and make it the greenest council in Scotland.In Haddington  Lammermuir, Jackie Swailes will contest the election.A business manager for the Green group of councillors in Edinburgh and a keen walker, on why she is standing for election Jackie says: ldquoI firmly believe that everyone should be given the opportunity to vote Green and send a message to the council that we must meet our net-zero obligations."Our campaign will bring forward ideas to improve the lives of East Lothian residents and build a supportive and inclusive community.It was confirmed last month that Tim Porteus would contest the by-election and the May  full council elections for the party in the Preston Seton Gosford ward.Tim works for an early-years charity that helps children and families. He lives in Prestonpans with his we Kate and three youngest children, who all attend schools in the town.Outside of work, he also enjoys hill-walking, history, folklore and storytelling ndash he writes the weekly Tims Tales column in the Courier.Lorna Slater MSP said: ldquoIrsquove seen first-hand the amazing work charities, social enterprises and community organisations do in Dunbar and across East Lothian."If elected, our Green candidates will help boost these organisations further and ensure a better, brighter future for the county.ldquoEast Lothian is a beautul part of the world to live and work, but it is not without its challenges. The Green candidates I spoke to are brimming with ideas to transform East Lothian and deliver real positive change.ldquoThis is a very strong slate of candidates who will bring real-world expertiseelected to the council and Irsquom delighted to give them my full support.The party is still to confirmit will stand a candidate in the Tranent, Macmerry and Wallyford ward.Simon Francis, co-convenor of the East Lothian Green Party, said: I would urge everyone to vote  for Scottish Green candidates in May  and trust them to serve the communities they love.The Greens are the first party to announce a full slate of candidates for next Mays council elections.Labour has so far announced four candidates: sitting councillors Shamin Akhtar and John McMillan in the Haddington and Lammermuir ward, and Fiona Dugdale and Colin McGinn in the Tranent, Wallyford and Macmerry ward, are all seeking re-election.The Liberal Democrats have also announced that Stuart Crawford will stand for them in the Haddington and Lammermuir ward.Meanwhile, it has also been previously confirmed that Conservative councillors Jane Henderson and Craig Hoy, Labour pair Jim Goodfellow and Fiona ODonnell, and the SNPs Paul McLennan will not be seeking re-election. Mr Hoy and Mr McLennan were both elected to the Scottish Parliament in May.

title: covid-scotland-booster-jabs-appear-vaccine-passports-december-9
story: Speaking on Good Morning Scotland, John Swinney said that proof of the booster jab would appear on vaccine passports for international travel from Thursday December .He added that this would be extended to the domestic vaccine certicationscheme, however this would take slightly longer to implement.When asked whether booster jabs would be included in the vaccine passport scheme, the deputy first minister said: "For international travel it will from  December."And we will expand that for domestic certication but that will take us a little more time to do that. But the critical requirement is for international travel and those changes will be applied from  December."According to the Scottish government, the NHSScotlandCovid Status app will update on Thursday December  to show proof of the booster jab.Depending on the settings on your phone, this will either update automatically or will require you to do it manually.If you need to update your app manually, you can do so by going to the app store and clicking on the small person icon in the top right corner.This will take you to your account details, where it will show you a list of the apps you have downloaded on your phone.Next to the app, there should be an option to update.The Scottish government has said that it will take dfering times for the update to roll out everywhere, but that it is currently underway as of lunch time on Thursday.To travel to some countries, you must have been fully vaccinated against Covidwithin a certain time limitprior to your visit, which ranges from -days to a year.With Covid jabs rolled out from late last year, it means that some people will already be barred from travelthey cannot provide proof of a booster jab.Proof of a booster jab will therefore help people to meet the vaccination requirements of certain countries.All adults in Scotland will be offered a booster vaccine as advised by the JCVI after results showed a third vaccine signicantly improved protection against serious infection.The booster jabs aim to curb a potentialwave of infections caused by the Omicron iant.So far, everyone aged  and over and people who are clinically vulnerable have been invited to book their booster jabs in Scotland.But soon, everyone over the age of  will beable to book a booster jab.These third doses will be offered no less than three months after the second dose of the vaccine was administered.This time frame between second vaccine and booster jab has been cut from six months to three, as advised by the JCVI.

title: covid-scotland-get-proof-booster-jab-vaccine-passport-app
story: To travel to some countries, you must have been fully vaccinated against Covidwithin a certain time limitprior to your visit, which ranges from -days to a year.With Covid jabs rolled out from late last year, it means that some people will already be barred from travelthey cannot provide proof of a booster jab.Proof of a third vaccinewill therefore help people to meet the vaccination requirements of certain countries.While proof of booster jabs was introduced in England in November, the update of the Scottish NHS vaccine passport app is taking place today.Heres how to get proof of the booster jab for international travel.According to the Scottish government, the NHS Scotland Covid Status app will update today to show proof of the booster jab.Depending on the settings on your phone, this will either update automatically or will require you to do it manually.If you need to update your app manually, you can do so by going to the app store and clicking on the small person icon in the top right corner.This will take you to your account details, where it will show you a list of the apps you have downloaded on your phone.Next to the app, there should be an option to update.The Scottish government has said that it will take dfering times for the update to roll out everywhere, but that it is currently underway as of lunch time on Thursday.You can download your vaccine passport on your smartphonevia theNHS Scotland Covid Status App.Simply head to the app store on your device and search NHS Scotland Covid Status App, which is free to download.You must firstly read andagree to the privacy policy which explains how the app works.Then you can either sign-inyou have previously made an account or sign upyou are yet to create one.If you are signing up, it will ask you to very your identity by uploading a photo of your passport or driving license and scanning your face with your camera.Once you have veried your identity, you can sign up by entering your email address and sending a verication code to this address.It will then ask you to enter the verication code before creating a password and confirming your account.You will be asked for your CHI number, however it is not a problemyou dont know it - you can skip this step by clicking "No" whenaskedyou know your number.The app will then display your name and date of birth as shown on your ID, and ask for the gender towhich you identy.You must then create a memorable  number pin.This is the final step in creating your account.The app should then show your vaccine status, including details of initial twojabs and the booster vaccine, barcodes for each and theof time since each of these vaccinations.Each time you sign into the app you will be asked to enter the memorable code.

title: covid-scotland-current-restrictions
story: The Scottish government is responsible for its own response to the pandemic, and therefore implements its own restrictions and measures surrounding Covid.While the prime minister yesterday implemented new measures in England, many of these were already in place in Scotland.Here is everything you need to know about the current Covid restrictions in Scotland...These are the current Covid regulations in place in Scotland:There are dferent rules depending on whether it is the newOmicron iant or the Delta iant.Anyone who tests positive forOmicron iant in Scotland must self isolate for  days.All close contacts of suspected Omicron infections must self isolate for -days, whether they are fully vaccinated or not.People will be told when they receive their PCR resultsthey have the Omicron iant.Anyone who tests positive for any iant of Covid- must self-isolate for -days.However,this is not the Omicron iant there are dferent rules for close contacts who are fully vaccinated.If you are fully vaccinated and a close contact of someone who tests positive for non-Omicron Covid, you must isolate until you get a PCR test.Ifyourresult then comes back negative and youremain asymptomatic, you will no longer have to isolate.Howeveryou are not vaccinated or only partially vaccinated and are identied as a close contact of someone with Covid,you must isolate for -days regardless of the result of your PCR test.The travel rules are the same across the UK.Everyone travelling from overseas must take a pre-departure and post-arrival test regardless of vaccination status.You must take a test within -hours before your flightto the UK, and test within -hours of your arrival in the UK, isolating until you receive these results.If you are fully vaccinated and receive a negative result, you can leave isolation.If you are not fully vaccinated you must isolate for -days and take a further day- test.If you are travelling from a country on the red list, you must isolate in a quarantine hotel.Tweeting on Wednesday night, first minister Nicola Sturgeon said: "Re UK gov announcement of Covid Plan B today, all these protections are already in place in and have helped us get Delta cases down."Tough question we all face in period ahead is whether these protections will be strong enough against a rapidly spreading Omicron ianthellip"Even Omicron doesnrsquot cause more severe disease, the numbers of people who might be infected by its faster spread will create big challenges for NHS and economy - so we need to consider carefullywhat proportionate response needed."In meantime, all of us complying strictly with current protections will help. And evenyou feel angry with a politician just now, please remember just how important compliance is for the health  safety of you, your loved ones and the country"

title: runs-scotland-investigation-scotlands-corridors-power-full
story: Our subscribers will get exclusive access to the people and organisationswith signicant influence over so many aspects of our lives.From the hundreds of secret lobbying meetings to who really runs Scotlands wind farms, whisky and media - the investigation will leave no stone unturned in a bid to stimulate discussion and debate.Here, you can find every article published in the week-long investigation so far - with this piece being updated daily with new exclusive stories.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today by taking out a subscription for just pound for two months here.Hundreds of meetings between Scottish ministers and multinationals, wealthy iniduals and other influentialorganisationswere left off the lobbying register in  due to loopholes in legislation, The Ferret can reveal.Analysis of Scottish Government ministersrsquoengagements in shows that meetings, potentially of key public interest, were not in the register, including those between ministers andcompaniesawarded multi-million poundUK and Scottish contracts to supply the NHS in the run-up to Covid-.Read the full scale of unrecorded discussions here.Professional lobbyists, including former politicians, advisors and a former minister have met with Scottish Government representatives on behalf of clients  times since March , The Ferret can reveal.Scotlandis home to dozens of public relations, think-tanks and consultancy firms, including several formed by or employing people who served in the upper echelons of government.Find out the whos who of professional lobbyists here.Questions have been raised over the power and influence of energycompaniesfollowing analysis by The Ferret revealing how key sectors dominate Scottish lobbying.The Ferretcategorisedorganisationsthat lobbied Scottish Government ministers since the register was introduced in  to increase transparency.Read the full exclusive analysis here.Bigbusinessincluding oil and renewable energy, farming, fishing, finance and whisky dominated Scotland Office ministersrsquo meetings last year, analysis by The Ferret has found.We looked at all external meetings logged in  by Alister Jack, Secretary of State forScotland, UK Government ministers for Scotland David Duguid and Iain Stewart, as well as Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross, who was deputy Secretary of State until he resigned in May that year.Read the full report exclusively here.The number ofcompaniesregistered in tax havens investing in Scotland over the last decade has increased by nearly  per cent.Analysis of Scottish Governmentdataby The Ferret found that in  there were  firms registered in the Cayman Islands, Bermuda and British Virgin Islands operating, compared to  in . Their collective turnover last year amounted to just over poundbn.Read the full exclusive story here.Nearly a third of Scotlandrsquos biggest wind farms have owners with links to offshore tax havens in the Cayman Islands, Luxembourg, Guernsey and Jersey.An investigation by The Ferret has also revealed that  of the largest  wind farms are ultimately ownedoutwithScotland in England, Spain, France, Germany, Norway, China and where.Read the full report here.Nearly  per cent of malt whisky distilleries are ultimately owned bycompaniesoutside Scotland with wealthy people linked to the industry including a French fashion billionaire, an Australian yoghurt tycoon, a Swiss philanthropist and Thailandrsquos richest man.The Ferret can reveal that of the Scots distilleries only a thirdare owned by Scottish firms.Read the full story here.Ten of Scotlands major newspapers are owned by just three men: Rupert Murdoch, Lord Rothermere and Frederick Barclay. They are all billionaires who, personally or through their businesses, have used thelawto avoid paying tax.An analysis by The Ferret reveals that all but one of Scotlands national newspapers, the Sunday Post, are owned in other countries.Read the full storyhereFive privatecompanieswho employ around three quarters of the workforce in Scotlandrsquos arms industry had thousands ofclosed doormeetings with the UK Government between  and .As part of TheFerretrsquosWho Runs Scotlandinvestigation we looked at firmsoperating in Scotlandrsquosdefenceindustry and examined data about them obtained by the Campaign Against Arms Trade .Read the full report here.The chief executives of quangos appointed by Scottish Government ministers were paid over poundm in total last year, leading to ldquoexcessive pay gaps between those at the top and lower paid public sector workers, The Ferret has found.In the course of ourresearchwe looked at the salaries ndash before bonuses or pension tops-up ndash of  leaders of quangos . There are just over  quangos in Scotland, which include Scottish governmentpublic andhealthbodies, executive agencies, non-ministerial offices and commissions.Read the full exclusive story here.Women board members appointed to Scotlandrsquos public bodies get paid half a million pounds less than their male counterparts, despite a drive for gender equality, The Ferret can reveal.Published pay arrangements for board members across  dferent public bodies, where appointments are largely overseen by the Scottish Government, show there are now virtually equal numbers of men and women serving on them.Read the full story here.Influential bankers,retired senior civil servants, well-connected industry insiders, powerful chief executives and former politicians - meet Scotlandrsquos quango class, the people who serve on the boards of Scotlandrsquos public bodies.Some roles are unpaid, and manyworkextra hours intheirdevotion to public service. But analysis by The Ferret of Scottish Government public board positionshas also found a web of influential connections binding many serving in the public sector.Read the full analysis here.So who runs Scotland  Thatrsquos been the central question of The Ferret and The Heraldrsquos week-long investigation.Along the way wersquove examined the corridors of power and looked at who gets the most access to ministers ndash and who doesnrsquot.Find out the top most influential people in Scotland here.Scotlandrsquos biggest private landowner has been attacked as ldquomanipulative and ldquoundemocratic after The Ferret revealed that his company lobbied the Scottish Government to stymie plans for a spaceport in Sutherland.A letter released under freedom of informationlawshows thatWildland Limitedmdash which runs three large estates acrossScotlandfor Danish billionaire,Anders Holch Povlsenmdash warned the former ruraleconomyminister, Fergus Ewing, that its planned investments could be endangered by the spaceport.Read the full story here.Scotlandneeds a radical sht in the way that power and influence are distributed to help address democratic deficits and rebuild trust in the political process, The Ferret has been told.Politicians and campaigners reacting to our week-long investigation ndash Who Runs Scotland ndash claimed it has revealed deep flaws in our transparency legislation and a heavy reliance on big businesses based outwith Scotland, including those with links to tax havens.Read the full final story here.

title: subscribe-herald-just-2
story: We want to bring you the best The Herald has to offer every day, from our unrivalled news and political coverage to our exclusive investigations.For just pound for two months, you can instantly read columns from your favoritecolumnistsincluding Brian Taylor, Alison Rowat, Mark Smith, and Iain Machiwhirter, and get the latest news and updates straight to your inbox with our tailored newsletters.When you head over to our subscriptions page yoursquoll see three options:Our specialoffer can be found under the ldquoPremium Plus plan under the option ofpoundfor two months, then pound. monthly afterwardsyou decide to stay with us.A subscription will give you access to unrivaled coverage as well as a number of unmissable perks.With that subscription, yoursquoll see % fewer adverts on our websiteand have unlimited access to all our stories, including premium articles.This means you will be able to readThe Heralds online coverage from our award-winning team uninterrupted.As a Herald subscriber, you will also have access to exclusive "Premium" articles. Around one in five of our stories are onlyavailable to people who have signed up for a Herald subscription.These articles are the very best of what we do - written by ourtop writers across a range of specialisms, from politics, to sport, to business, to arts. They could be analysis, comment, insight, interviews, features, or exclusive investigations.We also cannot forget about Voices Live, our section created specically to give our online subscribers exclusive, instant analysis on some of the largest stories in the Scottish news scene each day.As a subscriber, youll instantly have access to our new and improved newsletters on The Herald.You can sign up to all our newsletters here.Every weekday at pm, you can get our brand new evening political newsletter, Unspun, straight to your inbox.It promises readers an exclusive analysis of the day in Scottish politics - and a look at whats coming next.Finally, you will also get access to our enhanced digital package including a news app to keep you up to date on the go and our e-edition of the paper.You can enjoy the digital page-turning edition of The Herald  Herald on Sunday as well as our magazines and special publications.Subscribe to The Herald and dont miss a single word from your favourite columnists and reports by clicking here.
